nodes.bodyText: From a user point of view, this seems unnecessary.  If they know the versionId, entryType should be irrelevant.
if you agree with @coverbeck, then I can determine it that way instead.

I'd rather the endpoint search through both tables than require the client to specify the entry type.  Otherwise when we add a different entry type things could be weird from the client side (for example "service" being passed in)
There's a constant for "bearer" somewhere
I think this should be the versions resource instead
This should probably just be a list of DescriptorLanguage.FileType enums
I originally had it that way, but when I was writing the tests it kept saying it expected a list of strings anyway.
It probably converts the enum to a string, but for the swagger UI it is better if it is an enum since it will (I think) add a dropdown to the input with all the possible values.
using enum now
something something verison.getSourceFiles(); instead of a separate line for tag and workflowVersion
The "if" statement can be collapsed
Collapsed in two ways... You don't need the curly braces, and you can just return contains(...
This should use OpenAPI annotations instead.  I believe there's testing utilities for openapi client so you don't have to worry about that part.

I think this should be hierarchical.
/workflows/<workflowid>/versions/<versionid>/sourcefiles

And the corresponding one for tags.

The hierarchy is a common RESTful pattern
Your way relies on ids of workflow versions and tags always being unique, which they are now, but who knows, some day that won't be.

See if anybody else agrees with me first though.
If you do it that way, then you should probably add the endpoints to WorkflowResource and DockerRepoTagResource.
Ya, this was my first thought too.  The downside is you'd have two endpoints instead of one.  you'd also need the entry id
changed to two endpoints
Looks like a category, but why is there a category being created?

nodes.bodyText:
You should ideally call TagDAO.findById() instead. That way you will fetch only one version from the DB and not the 600+ versions some repos have.
The problem is that you'll also need to validate that tagId belongs to containerId, otherwise you could end up fetching a tag for a different container. If you fetch all of the parent's versions to verify, then you're back to square one.

You make Version.entry field public, so you can do the check.
You write a new query that fetches a version given a containerId and tagId as params.

The second option would execute the fastest, but would be a little more work.
Same comment as for tags
Not necessary to create a new named query and function.  Just make versionDAO constructor public and use versionDAO get by id.
Probably don't even need to change visibility since TagDAO is a VersionDAO.
it's so that the other endpoint could share the same code, since it's unusual for workflowversion to call tagDAO
I made a new query because it was asked to verify that the version belongs to the entry requested, and that it'd be the the quicker option, but I'll use versionDAO instead.
Two endpoints is fine, but this line and every line below it should just be the same implementation as the other one, just use a function
It probably doesn't hurt, but both tagids and entryids are unique, so it seems like the parentid check is redundant.
The concern I had was making sure that doing GET /workflows//versions/ doesn't work. Especially if the user doesn't have permissions to another workflow.
I think the checkUser function already accomplishes that.
Yeah so checkOptionalAuthRead() checks if the entry is published or the user has access, so it takes care of the permission issue.
It only takes care of the permissions issue if the version belongs to the entry that you checked. :) Which is why I think you do need the parent id here. Or maybe we're saying the same thing.
Yeah, i think we're saying the same thing. I'm keeping the parentid

I only thought of this after you responded to my last comment, but you could just query the source files from the database directly. Any time we are filtering Hibernate objects, it's an indicator of a potential area where you could have the DB do the work for you.
Is the common use case in the UI expected to be invoking going to be using the filetypes parameter, and if so, what type? Will it just be the .dockstore.yml? If that is a common case, it's a slightly stronger argument to fetch from the DB; if a workflow has n descriptor files and one .dockstore.yml, just fetch the .dockstore.yml from the DB.
This is probably way overkill, and we risk having too many one-offs, so I'm leaning towards not doing it, but throwing it out for consideration.
The typical pattern for naming named queries is to use the package name, although we're not always consistent in it (io.dockstore.webservice.core.Version.findVersionInEntry).
These two tests should be using the OpenAPI client. Instead of io.swagger.client.ApiClient.
Remove mention of "workflow" from this (because of tools and services)
User needs to be set to hidden in OpenAPI for it to not show up here.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -4349,6 +4411,68 @@ paths:
       - bearer: []
       tags:
       - workflows
+  /workflows/{workflowId}/workflowVersions/{workflowVersionId}/sourcefiles:
+    get:
+      description: Retrieve sourcefiles for an entry's version
+      operationId: getWorkflowVersionsSourcefiles
+      parameters:
+      - description: Workflow to retrieve the version from.
+        in: path
+        name: workflowId
+        required: true
+        schema:
+          format: int64
+          type: integer
+      - description: Workflow version to retrieve the version from.
+        in: path
+        name: workflowVersionId
+        required: true
+        schema:
+          format: int64
+          type: integer
+      - description: List of file types to filter sourcefiles by
+        in: query
+        name: fileTypes
+        schema:
+          items:
+            enum:
+            - DOCKSTORE_CWL
+            - DOCKSTORE_WDL
+            - DOCKERFILE
+            - CWL_TEST_JSON
+            - WDL_TEST_JSON
+            - NEXTFLOW
+            - NEXTFLOW_CONFIG
+            - NEXTFLOW_TEST_PARAMS
+            - DOCKSTORE_YML
+            - DOCKSTORE_SERVICE_YML
+            - DOCKSTORE_SERVICE_TEST_JSON
+            - DOCKSTORE_SERVICE_OTHER
+            - DOCKSTORE_GXFORMAT2
+            - GXFORMAT2_TEST_FILE
+            - DOCKSTORE_SWL
+            - SWL_TEST_JSON
+            type: string
+          type: array
+      requestBody:

nodes.bodyText:
Should probably put a comment mentioning that this namedQuery is to double check that the user didn't put a workflowId they have access to with a workflowVersionId (from a different hidden workflow) they don't have access to.
My first thought when looking at this was that the versionId isn't unique and needs the parentId.
This kind of bothers me.  Try putting @ApiIgnore or ApiOperation(hidden = true), for the method and see if it gets rid of this in swagger completely.
